pros: Work life balance and picking your own schedule
cons: Not having PTO roll over

pros: Good doctors and nurses thats about it
cons: Working here has been a nightmare. The facility is inaccessible and has no parking around not for employees. The floors along with the rooms, are not always well cleaned. I have seen blood in bathrooms after "being cleaned". The management does not care about its employees. In spite the fact that we worked in a hospital, we had to pay a big chunk of money to be insured. The worst part is the colleagues and the HR they are very self centred, they do not care about work morals or ethics. The HR is very unresponsive and if they pick up the phone they are so unkind and act like they own the hospital. Please remember you are just employees who work for others. Specially that woman called Kaitlin she is so rude. They do not compensate those who leave or honour their work by giving them their legal rights. Save yourself a traumatic experience and find another hospital to work at.

job_title: Linen Distribution Associate in Washington, DC
pros: The SEIU (union) will pay for up to $4000 of any educational programs that will contribute to the hospital.
cons: It’s how they treat people. The moment their rate of upset calls for linen go up, all of the associates grow targets on their backs, with exception of seniority who have been there for 20+ years, the leads and employees they are scared of. They micromanage to the extent of hiring spies to monitor your work. Going behind you to other departments inquiring them to monitor your every move & report back. They only care for the patients enough for their paychec & encourage associates to become desensitized to them. If a director dose not like you he will let the leads bully you. If a director has a closed door meeting with the leads and if they are talking about you; you will know it, because they turn into wolves; it’s a wrap. They will give you hell. When they feel intimidated & want an employee to quit; they will burn them out with assignments, take their breaks away, back them down in meetings, talk to you like a dog in front of other staff outside the department & ask you to do weird things or threaten you with termination. I was told of a man who they threatened with termination because he didn’t wear underwear. The director will allow this, and even turn a blind eye or join the fun and laugh at it. Any complaints will make things worse. The leads are always right. The leadership never gives pats on the back for good work. It’s all about what you have done for me lately. And you better have had done a lot because it’s never enough!

job_title: Student Nurse Extern in Washington, DC
pros: I loved working here during nursing school. I really felt that this experience boosted my confidence and helped me build strong connections with staff on the unit. The unit you work for really puts in time to make sure that you feel comfortable and that your time is valuable.
cons: I have nothing bad to say, I would recommend this program to anyone!

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Washington, DC
pros:
You’ll see things you learned about in nursing school, but you instructors said you may go your whole career and never see. 
The sickest of the sick come here so if you want high acuity and all the resources that western medicine can offer, then this is the place for you. 
Great education program for new graduate nurses, really supports you within that first year!
Health benefits are incredible!
cons:
The volumes are SO high and staffing is always short; everyone feeling spread so thin to provide good care to these very sick patients. 
Terrible culture within the hospital: very difficult to get the floors to take report, they pick and choose patients and nursing supervisors side with them leaving the ED to continue to board the patient for no real reason and takes a space away from emergently ill patients. This results in terrible patient flow and low patient satisfaction. 
Very easy place to get burnt out in
Poor work ethic and lacking team work are praised/promoted while hard workers who work with the team to get things done quickly and correctly go without recognition
Lack of space and resources 
The workflow for all the different resources and communication etc (the system) is fraught with issues causing lots of delays in patient care

pros: The patients really do have access to some of the best care in the world. People do a lot with whatever they have. Nurses and nurse managers can often be spectacular. Teamwork is important to and respected by most managers. Most employees treat each other kindly and respectfully.
cons:
Schedule not flexible. Everyone must physically punch in (and out for most people) everyday. The rule is no working remotely, even for people who are not doctors or nurses and who just work in offices.  But some people get to break the rule if their manager feels like it. This rule is very outdated for today's offices-- no laptops offered. Good managers get better; not so good or uncaring managers can stay that way without being "coached" for as long as the work gets done. Lots of jobs there, but not very much care for lower-level employees to grow and get better positions. Middle managers are lucky if there is a next step up for them. Very slow and relatively expensive cafeteria (for what you get) makes lunchtime a pain. Parking and parking shuttles are not convenient at all. 
Appreciation is shown weird ways. Lots of little prizes but few things that actually matter, like vacation days or generous holiday leave.

review_title: I've worked here through OK times and terrible times (snowstorms, strikes, you name it).
pros: If you can work here, you can work anywhere. Great place to learn. Highest acuity critical care of all DC metro hospitals - we are where other hospitals send their sickest patients. Young culture.
cons: Senior management is awful, and unit management is inconsistent. Favoritism is rampant.  Nurses are frequently held accountable for the laziness of support staff (including, but not limited to, dietary, environmental services, PCTs, and unit clerks). High staff turnover with a revolving door of new grads and nurses who only want 6 months - 1 year experience so they can move on and work elsewhere. Almost everyone I started with as a new grad and during bridge transfers to other specialties is long gone. Unions (NNU and SEIU) protect terrible staff.

job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Washington, DC
pros: There are great co-workers in other department. They are friendly.
cons: This department has a VERY high turnover primarily because of management of the department. The managers are very unprofessional in speech and attire. They are not supportive and uncaring. The salary is very low compared to the amount of work required. Long hours and mandatory evening and weekend work w/ no overtime compensation. Those requiring supervision for the clinical license will be waiting a while. It will not be earned in 2 yrs. There is little to no career advancement in this dept. Position is 99% discharge planning  and not really social work. You have to beg to take off of work.  Don't be fooled RUN!!

review_title: Not the place you see in the commercials
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Washington, DC
pros:
The sickest patients in the area are sent here.
Nurses here 10 yrs or more in a specialty area have seen and treated some of the most complex cases of medical and surgical conditions.
cons:
Doesn't staff adequately, 
Rushed pace is unsustainable, 
Doesn't value retaining experienced RNs,
New RNs frequently trained by RNs with less than 2 yrs experience.

job_title: Special Police Officer in Washington, DC
pros: Sergeants and Management are very supportive of our role protecting the hospital from the inner and outer threats that may occurre through out the day. Department Provides quarterly firearm training for level III officers and annual DC criminal code and nonviolent crisis intervention training across the board as well with defensive tactics. Salary could be a little better but we are highest paid hospital spo agency in the district, so no complaints there. Benefits are great and leave a rarely get denied unless we are short of staff.
cons: All staff needs to make the realization that security are not here to bully or intimidate people into submission. 90 % of disorderly calls are patients and visitors that are dissatisfied with the patient care they are receiving and just need somebody to hear there complaints and not to be ignored.

pros: Working in healthcare you feel as though you are helping someone in need.  The benefits are good.
cons: Management is the worse.  They take a lot of courses to become good to great and they still don't know to apply it their teams.  I have worked on both the management and associate side so I understand what it takes.  If you are at MedStar and really look at the faces of the associates you will see depression.

job_title: Patient Care Manager in Washington, DC
pros: The company offers great tools to be an effective associate such as the Nurse residency program and nurse leadership academy. Overall senior Leadership is supportive of professional development.
cons: The collective bargain agreement makes it challenging to effectively manage your department. The hospital pushes for various new initiatives but lacks monitoring after execution. On some units, patient care managers may start the day at 7am and will be sent home early afternoon to come back and work a night shift if staffing is poor. The level of professionalism could improve.

pros: Learning in a teaching environment where new procedures, medications and treatments are at the front lines is awesome for the patient first and foremost, also for the caregivers. There is never a dull day.
cons: Being switched around from area to area on a daily basis, not having enough staff members to fill needed slots for time off and vacations.

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Washington, DC
pros: I have worked here for 3 years and I have had great experiences and love my coworkers and team so much.
cons: Some of the managers make it seem like they only notice when things are negative and you never get any feedback on the work you do day in and day out. There are issues with some staff members bulling others into giving them patient assignments that are less work.

review_title: Good Experience, but not worth working here long
pros: Sick patients and good variety of patient experience.  I've learned a lot in my time here and don't regret having chose this as my first place to work.
cons: Management is super stingy with staffing and money. These patients can be very busy but they don't always recognize that. I'm sure we have plenty of patient issues related to this. It's frustrating to see staff getting let go due to budget issues while John Sullivan gets millions in bonus's.  Nurses aren't valued or paid well after getting experience and so they leave.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Good benefits, good salary after you have been there for awhile.
cons: Very "us against them culture". Management only cares about the bottom line and not the relationship with staff or  patient care. Do more with less nurses, supplies, ancillary staff. Nurses do not get lunch breaks and are expected to work 12 hr shifts without eating or using the bathroom. Our patients are sick. I am an experienced RN and I am fearful about harming a patient because my assignment is unsafe.

job_title: Clinical Nurse III in Washington, DC
pros: If you can make it here, you'll make it anywhere! This hospital sees everything under the sun. I feel fortunate that my education and experiences have grown so much by working here. My co-workers (nurses, doctors, respiratory therapists, clerks, etc.) make a great team, too.
cons: It's a high pressure environment, not only because of acuity, but also because of staffing issues. The culture here is very political because of management-union relations. Experiences vary widely based on your unit. And ICUs seem to take priority for staffing, which is problematic if you don't actually work in an ICU.

review_title: A wonderful learning experience from a family of professionals
pros:
This is a level one trauma facility where you get to see it all. You experience everything from gunshots/stabbings to heart attacks/strokes and rare cancer/disorders. If you want variety... 
The benefits are great and the people you work with are family. 
They work hard to provide staff with the latest technology.
cons: Can be a bit of a 'boys club'... the opportunity for advancement is based little on skill but more on who you know. It does feel a bit understaffed at times but I think that is true everywhere. Parking is poor. The place is clean but needs to step it up a bit.

pros: Pay. Which is why the majority of staff that commute long distances work there
cons:
I was an RN in a specialty unit as well as a low level manager there:
- high work load with little institutional support in terms of equipment and personel
- employees that are unfriendly and abusive... if you are polite  (ie. say "please" and "thank you") others take it as a sign of weakness and try to take advantage of you.  The only way to get things done there is to be as rude as everyone else is
- the facilities are delapidated and dirty (unless you work in a unit that makes the hospital money).  For example, for the first 2 - 3 years that I worked there we would admit critical care patients without enough reliably functioning monitors.  Our upper management was well aware of this.  When the monitors were finally replaced they replaced them with used equipment that was marginally more servicable
- revolving door of all management with no stability.... the only ones that were allowed to stick around were the ones that were hired from the inside and sucessfully maintained the status quo  by not rocking the boat of senior union staff or attracting the attention of their own higher ups.
- a union contract that is abusive to anyone there less than 10 years: on the last contract that I was there for, junior staff was handed a cut in differential pay while the senior staff maintained their differential pay as well as recieved their yearly raise.
- overt racism: when I first started working there I noticed that some of the staff would referr to unidentified black patients as "Jan".... imagine my surprise when I found out later that this was an acronym for "Just Another N-word".  They stopped saying that around me, but I am not foolish enough to think that it stopped all together.
-  institutional racism many non-white workers but very few if any non-white upper level management.  Also, ther is a large amount of white suburban/ rural staff that travels to work for higher wages in the city and the local largly non-white patient and staff population don't always play nice in the sandbox and I witnessed many "us v. them" conversations and situations 
- management and the union are too focused on battleing one another for them to spend money, time, or concern on the front line staff 
- Poor worker moral... any wonder why?  It is infectious and palpable.

pros: Lots of available OT for the moment, but after the staffing crisis subsides, I'm sure that will go by the wayside again.
cons: Difficult patient population, old and run down equipment, unsupportive management, employees pay to park and even then, they might have you park miles away from the hospital and use a shuttle to get to work.

pros: Cultural diversity is wonderful.peer support is great  staff interaction  well promoted when addressing our clients needs and problems we save a lot of lives
cons: IT support is nineteenth century-- that is to say the same since 1899

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Washington, DC
pros: I've worked in many hospitals and nursing homes in the DC area, and this is the only job that didn't make me feel like I was easily replaceable. They wanted me to be a part of their team because they believed that if I was happy to be there, then I would be able to provide quality healthcare to my patients. I am grateful to be a MedStar, and I look forward to advancing within the organization. They have flexible scheduling and opportunities for educational assistance.
cons: Parking off-site on weekdays and having to take a free shuttle.

review_title: Patient safety is an issue, get to see a lot
pros: Good variety of patient diagnoses, diverse staff, good benefits, good support from union
cons: At times RN to patient ratios are concerning, at one point charge RN had 5 patients (not the first time I've seen it happen), unsupportive and occasionally bullying management, no monetary benefits from being charge RN or preceptor

review_title: I work in the er and I take the people who come in with pain in there chest so I am the ekg tech
pros: You get to meet different people and see a lot of things. It makes me feel good because I am helping people plus Washington Hospital Center has the best Cardio Doctors.
cons: It is a very fast pace job and you have to be on point at all times

job_title: Financial Clearance Representative in Washington, DC
pros: Great benefits, chance for educational development with classes offered, have some great doctors and knowledgeable.
cons: Watch everything you do, not enough staff to help patients, Staff  is not that professional in some departments. Hard to make advancements unless you know someone in that department. Lots of drama in certain departments.

pros: There are so many opportunities for growth at the Center. One can start in an entry position and can work their way up. The benefits are also great.  There is a tuition benefit for all the use to their benefit.
cons: Nothing bad to say about the hospital, except, don't think your just gonna be there for a year or two.  It's like Hotel California, you get so involved in the culture that the time flies by.

review_title: Pretty good entity to work for.
pros: Union membership was a plus. Loved the medical benefits, 100% coverage for Medstar network.  Work-life balance was tolerable.
cons: Management was not very supportive at times. Not a lot of respect for employees with long employment history. Not very much recognition for extra effort.

review_title: Interesting place to spend a few years
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Washington, DC
pros: Protected staffing ratios in ICU, parking available on-site for $20/month, interesting learning opportunities at Level I trauma center; due to large size, lots of other internal clinical and non-clinical opportunities for nurses if you grow tired of your job
cons: Facility is old and in great need of repair, very low quality service staff (cleaning, nutrition, etc), pay is lower compared to other area hospitals, professionalism among all employees (MDs, RNs, etc. included) is low

review_title: Working at WHC for many years has provided many learning opportunities throughout the years.
pros: Highly knowledgeable medical staff with state of the art technology.  Several great centers of excellence - Stroke, Cancer, Cardiology, and Cardiovascular Surgery.  Excellent Burn and Trauma services.  Great educational opportunities.
cons:
Older building, and crowded patient rooms.  
Congested campus.

review_title: Loved the people I worked with, the work environment and treatment of some staff, not so much
pros: The nurses and doctors are the absolute best on the neonatal units. Smart, kind, attentive, and hard-working.
cons: During my employment there were two strikes by the nurses because of conflicts between them and Medstar. They were not always treated as they should have been and the turnover rate was extremely high.

review_title: A promising place, but redistribute workload!
job_title: Meister / Lebens- und Geschäftscoach in Washington, DC
pros: Innovative organization. Evidence-based practice. High-reliability and accountability. The new CEO, Greg Argyros, is a huge improvement over John Sullivan. A great place to grow professionally! Overall I feel supported and happy here.
cons: Uneven distribution of workload. High-performing staff get more responsibilities, low-performing staff can skate by doing very little.

review_title: This has been an enriching career move. The jury is still out on advancement within."
pros:
Healthcare is a growing market.
Innovative employer willing to try new approaches.
Education rewarded.
Patient care areas generally nice.
cons:
Salary not quite there yet.
Bureaucracy and ego hurdles loom high.
Facilities outside patient care need updated.
Parking is a serious issue.

pros: Great pay when compared to other companies doing similar tasks. Great benefits for those who have become full-time. Great management
cons: This place can get extremely busy during the peak season. When this happens, people call in sick and you are forced to pick up the slack ten fold.

pros: Great nurses, great residency program for new graduate nurses, challenging but kind patients
cons: Awful staffing, overworked to death, burnt out, TERRIBLE manager, felt like I was not cared about or valued, one of my patients had cockroaches in his room, lazy staff members

review_title: It was a great opportunity to advance in my career with the skill sets I had and acquire new ones.
job_title: Patient Access Officer in Washington, DC
pros: It has great job opportunities,the best medical benefits, education and pay is not bad at all but most of all you meet some lifelong friends and comrades.
cons: because its a hospital your always expected to be there rain, sleet, snow or shine and that doesn't always work out for employees

job_title: Medical Office Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
There are little to no pros of MWHC.

One pro is the fact that they contain Panera, that's pretty much it.
cons:
I was a medical office assistant. Someone who sits in an office and responds to e-mails all day. I think the true colors showed for this organization where the administration was not allowed to work from home during the COVID19 pandemic.

The weeks of March 2nd and 16th, when the all the restrictions and bans for the coronavirus went into effect, MedStar Washington Hospital Center did nothing for their employees. Given the fact that it is a hospital, not every single person is needed in the hospital, especially administration who can reply and respond to e-mails from home. 

The more people in a facility, the more likely a virus is to spread. Especially a facility that has patients with coronavirus.
 And comparing to the other competing healthcare facilities in the are such as INOVA, who sent home the people who are non-clinical for the safety of their patients, employers and staff, MWHC and MedStar itself is behind on their time. 

Majority of the employers here have been working for 15+ years and are not aware of the new modern technology and privileges one should receive from an organization - something as simple as working from home. 

Working from home is rare if not non-existent. They will force you to come to work when you clearly have absolutely nothing to do during a global crisis.
And the crazy part is, there is an option to work from home! The MedStar IT department is able to set you up to work from home on any laptop/desktop  - but they will not allow you to. 

This is a 1 star hospital for a reason. Besides the fact that MWHC does not care about their employees during a global pandemic, they are a very disorganized, disgusting, facility and their 1 star reflects how poor of a healthcare facility it truly is. 

Bathrooms are never, ever clean, the floors are always dirty, the facility itself smells disgusting, big cockroaches EVERYWHERE. I was there for three years and our office got vacuumed 4 times- I would never, ever admit a family member or friend as a patient here. 

MedStar Washington Hospital Center DOES NOT care for their employees. i should not have been forced to go to work when all I did was reply to 5 or 6 e-mails a day. 

Not everyone is essential and it is wrong to have every employee come into the hospital during a global pandemic because it is just spreading the virus more.

All MWHC does is sweep any issues under the rug.

pros:
The job is easy if you like the fast food environment.
You can move up quickly if you start as a dishwasher.
cons:
Senior Management are not team players.
Lacks consistancy with the job flow.
Unprofessional atmosphere.
Little to no training.
Very low employee morale.
Very poor sanitation practices.

pros: Many opportunities to grow and work in different areas. Largest hospital in the metropolitan DC area and one of the best.
cons: There had been significant organizational leadership of the the years that I worked there and it created a very unhealthy work environment.

pros: Never late to work. Always go to work with excitement. Calmness in the presence of greatest stress and never subdued. Charge nurse responsibilities, Oncology experience. Certification in Case management.
